title: Personal Portfolio
intro: A multi-page website showcasing personal projects, my story, and ways to reach me.
detailText: This project provided me with great insight into the full website development process. The process was challenging since it involved many practices I had no experience with, such as content writing and layout design. I also faced many development issues as I tried to integrate technologies I hadn’t worked with before. This was also a greater scale project than I was used to working on, so keeping an organized file structure was difficult. However, these difficulties greatly added to my web development learning experience.

In case you’re curious, the steps I followed were: decide on website content to host, create/write this content, decide on the website's general architecture, sketch low-fidelity wireframes, design high-fidelity prototypes with Adobe XD, decide what technologies to build with, and develop the website.

On the programming side, I chose to build this site with React since I wanted to gain more experience with it and was also curious about using React Router to simulate multi-page navigation. To handle my contact form’s submission, I used the Formspree API along with the react-hook-form library to help with form validation. I also used Framer Motion and react-intersection-observer to implement some simple animations as an element was rendered or scrolled by. Most other functionalities were simply handled with useState and useEffect, like the mobile menu and slider within each project page.
Lastly, I built this website to be fully responsive starting with a mobile-first approach and used Sass partials to keep my styles organized and modular.

title: Filterable Listings App
intro: A React app that allows you to filter through a set of job listings based on job role, level, and technologies required.
detailText: This was my first project working with React. It was a great exercise to help me learn how dynamic web applications work. I chose to build it with React to help dynamically render different job listings as filtering categories changed.

The changing state of this app was managed using React hooks such as useState and useEffect. The initial set of displayed job listings are retrieved from a JSON file and these are then filtered through as the user selects category tags. The user is able to remove category tags from the filtering set one at a time or completely clear the set and view the initial job listings again.

Given mobile and desktop mockups, I built this app to be fully responsive by following a mobile-first approach. I used Sass partials and a BEM inspired class architecture to keep my styles organized and modular.

title: Manage Landing Page
intro: A fully responsive page featuring a vanilla JavaScript slider, complete with mobile hamburger menu.
detailText: This landing page was great at testing my responsive and ingenuity skills, it had plenty of layout shifts to accommodate for as breakpoints changed. These layout challenges were mainly in the features section, testimonial slider, and footer.

I learned the most, however, when working on the slider since I had to get it to lay out a specific way, function intuitively for various controls, and be responsive. Most of the JavaScript used for this project is to implement the slider functionality, which consists of event handlers for all slider controls executing appropriate transitions to desired slides.

The entire page was built to be fully responsive by referencing given mobile and desktop mockups and following a mobile-first approach. To keep my styles organized and modular, I used Sass partials and a BEM inspired class architecture.

title: Insure Landing Page
intro: A fully responsive page featuring multiple overlapping elements, complete with mobile hamburger menu.
detailText: This landing page was a nice challenge and learning experience. Implementing the responsive navigation bar with a hamburger menu and composing the hero with overlapping elements added some pleasant complexity.
The mobile hamburger’s open-close toggle was set up with vanilla JavaScript. The overlapping elements were achieved using CSS absolute positioning and z-index.

Given mobile and desktop mockups, I took a mobile-first approach and built this page to be fully responsive. I used Sass partials and a BEM inspired class architecture to keep my styles organized and modular.

title: Fylo Landing Page
intro: A simple 2-column layout landing page with single input forms and form validation.
detailText: This landing page was among the first landing pages I worked on. It served as an opportunity to further my experience laying out simple webpages, while also introducing some complexity through forms and form validation.

I used Sass to simplify development along with some vanilla JavaScript for form validation. Event handlers were used with HTML5’s checkValidity() method so that on each form’s submission the input constraints are checked, and any error stylings or messages are set when necessary.
I built this site to be fully responsive through referencing given mobile and desktop mockups and following a mobile-first approach.

title: Huddle Landing Page
intro: A simple HTML and CSS landing page with alternating feature cards and a 4-column footer.
detailText: As one of the first landing pages I worked on, my main purpose building this was to practice laying out webpages. The footer specifically proved to be a nice challenge for the desktop breakpoint.

Given mobile and desktop mockups, I took a mobile-first approach and built this page to be fully responsive. I used reusable classes and Sass nesting to simplify development, Sass variables to easily reference colors, and Flex ordering for the alternating feature cards.
Although Sass was not necessary for this simple project, I went ahead and used it to get more comfortable with it since I planned to use it for future projects.
